constructs.name: weekend_work_hours
constructs.description: Amount of time spent on work activities during weekend days

constructs.name: unfinished_weekday_tasks
constructs.description: Volume of work tasks not completed during the Monday-Friday work period that carry over

constructs.name: weekday_productivity
constructs.description: Efficiency and output during regular work hours on weekdays

constructs.name: workload_volume
constructs.description: Total amount of work tasks assigned or committed to in a given period

constructs.name: work_stress
constructs.description: Experienced stress, pressure, and anxiety related to work demands

constructs.name: work_rumination
constructs.description: Intrusive, repetitive thoughts about work during non-work time

constructs.name: sleep_quality
constructs.description: Restorative quality of sleep including ease of falling asleep and feeling rested

constructs.name: energy_levels
constructs.description: Physical and mental energy available throughout the day

constructs.name: boundary_enforcement
constructs.description: Active behaviors to separate work from personal time such as turning off notifications or leaving devices at office

constructs.name: weekend_social_commitments
constructs.description: Planned activities with family, friends, or community on weekends

constructs.name: weekend_recovery_activities
constructs.description: Engagement in hobbies, exercise, relaxation, and restorative non-work activities on weekends

constructs.name: planning_quality
constructs.description: How well work tasks are prioritized, scheduled, and organized during the week

constructs.name: physical_activity
constructs.description: Amount of physical exercise and movement during the day

constructs.name: work_guilt
constructs.description: Feelings of guilt or shame about not working or taking personal time

constructs.name: deadline_pressure
constructs.description: Proximity to and urgency of externally-imposed work deadlines

constructs.name: manager_weekend_communication
constructs.description: Whether managers or colleagues send work communications on weekends

constructs.name: job_role_demands
constructs.description: Structural demands of the job role including on-call requirements and client-facing responsibilities

constructs.name: organizational_culture
constructs.description: Workplace norms regarding work hours, availability expectations, and work-life balance values

constructs.name: workaholism_tendency
constructs.description: Trait-level tendency toward compulsive overworking and difficulty disengaging from work

constructs.name: boundary_setting_self_efficacy
constructs.description: Confidence in one's ability to successfully set and maintain work-life boundaries

constructs.name: social_support_availability
constructs.description: Availability of supportive relationships with family, friends, or partners

edges.description: Tasks not completed during the week create pressure to work on weekends to catch up
High work stress creates anxiety that drives compulsive checking and working on weekends
Intrusive work thoughts during weekends make it harder to resist the urge to work
Active boundary behaviors like turning off notifications reduce weekend work
Feeling guilty about not working drives compensatory weekend work behavior
Scheduled activities with others create competing demands that prevent weekend work
Engagement in hobbies and recovery activities provides alternatives to defaulting to work
Higher productivity during work hours means more tasks completed before the weekend
More total work assigned means more likely to have incomplete tasks at week end
Good planning and prioritization enables more focused efficient work
Better sleep enables better cognitive function and focus during work
Higher energy levels enable sustained focus and output during work hours
High stress impairs concentration and cognitive function reducing productivity
Good sleep directly determines daily energy levels
Regular physical activity increases sustained energy throughout the day
Physical activity promotes better more restorative sleep
Work stress causes rumination and physiological arousal that impairs sleep
Thinking about work at night disrupts ability to fall and stay asleep
Higher work stress leads to more intrusive thoughts about work during off-hours
Having incomplete tasks creates ongoing stress and pressure
Approaching deadlines increase experienced stress levels
Higher workload volume increases daily stress levels
Believing you can set boundaries enables actual boundary-setting behaviors
High stress makes it harder to maintain boundaries as anxiety pushes toward checking work
A culture expecting constant availability makes boundary enforcement socially costly
Weekend emails and messages from management directly trigger work responses
Imminent deadlines directly increase weekend work to meet them
Some roles structurally have higher baseline workload
Some roles like on-call positions structurally require weekend availability
Workaholic tendencies lead to more persistent thoughts about work
Workaholism makes it psychologically harder to maintain boundaries
Workaholic tendencies amplify guilt about taking time off
Cultures that valorize overwork increase guilt about not working
Weekend work crowds out time available for recovery activities perpetuating the cycle
Weekend recovery helps restore and improve sleep quality for the coming week
Recovery activities help reduce accumulated work stress
Working weekends perpetuates the stress cycle by preventing proper recovery
Having incomplete work creates guilt that persists into weekends
Having energy makes it more likely to engage in physical exercise
High stress reduces motivation and perceived time available for physical activity
Higher energy enables better executive function for planning and organizing work
Social commitments often involve recovery activities like shared meals or recreation
High stress leads to social withdrawal and canceling weekend plans
Guilt about not working leads to accepting additional tasks and commitments
Having supportive relationships increases likelihood of weekend social plans
Social support provides a buffer against work-related stress
Supportive relationships facilitate engagement in restorative weekend activities

indicators.name: weekend_work_browsing_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count work-related website visits and searches occurring on Saturday or Sunday only. Work-related includes: programming/technical documentation, work tools (Slack, GitHub, Jira, email clients), professional research, code-related searches. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: weekend_work_active_hours
indicators.how_to_measure: For Saturday and Sunday only: Count the number of distinct hour blocks (0-23) containing at least one work-related browse activity. For example, activity at 9:15 AM and 9:45 AM counts as 1 hour block; add activity at 2:30 PM for 2 total. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: late_weekday_work_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: For Monday through Friday only: Count work-related browsing activities occurring after 8:00 PM. Work-related includes programming documentation, work tools, professional research, code searches. If reviewing a weekend day, record 0.

indicators.name: friday_evening_work
indicators.how_to_measure: For Friday only: Record 1 if any work-related browsing occurs after 6:00 PM, record 0 if no work browsing after 6 PM on Friday. If reviewing any other day of the week, record 0.

indicators.name: work_hours_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: For weekdays (Mon-Fri) between 9 AM and 6 PM only: Count all work-related browsing activities including programming docs, technical searches, professional research, work tools like GitHub or Jira. If reviewing a weekend, record 0.

indicators.name: distraction_site_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: For weekdays (Mon-Fri) between 9 AM and 6 PM: Count visits to non-work sites including entertainment (YouTube for non-work, Netflix), social media, general news, shopping, games. If reviewing a weekend, record 0.

indicators.name: total_work_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count all work-related searches throughout the entire day, any day of week. Include programming topics, professional tools, technical documentation lookups, work project research.

indicators.name: distinct_work_topics
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the number of distinct work-related topics researched in the day. A topic is a distinct subject area (e.g., 'Haskell', 'TLS encryption', 'authentication', 'database queries'). Count each unique topic once regardless of how many times searched.

indicators.name: stress_wellness_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing stress or wellness related terms: stress, anxiety, burnout, mental health, relaxation, meditation, therapy, overwhelmed, panic, calm, wellness, headache, fatigue, insomnia.

indicators.name: late_night_health_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count health-related or symptom-related searches occurring after 9 PM. Include searches about physical symptoms, mental health, medical conditions, wellness topics.

indicators.name: evening_work_browsing
indicators.how_to_measure: Count work-related browsing activities between 6 PM and 11 PM, any day of week. Work-related means programming, work communication tools, professional research, technical documentation.

indicators.name: late_night_work_check
indicators.how_to_measure: Record 1 if any work-related browsing occurs after 10 PM, record 0 otherwise. Work-related includes work email, code searches, work documentation, Slack, Teams, GitHub.

indicators.name: sleep_related_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches for sleep-related topics: sleep, insomnia, sleep quality, tired, fatigue, sleep aids, melatonin, can't sleep, sleep tracker, sleep app, sleep schedule, nap.

indicators.name: last_activity_hour
indicators.how_to_measure: Record the hour (0-23) of the last browsing activity of the day. Example: last activity at 11:47 PM means record 23; last activity at 9:15 PM means record 21.

indicators.name: daily_activity_volume
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the total number of browsing activities (all searches and website visits) for the entire day. Count every entry in the browsing history for that day.

indicators.name: morning_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count all browsing activities occurring between 6 AM and 12 PM noon. Include all searches and visits in this time window.

indicators.name: work_stops_by_evening
indicators.how_to_measure: Record 1 if there is NO work-related browsing after 7:00 PM. Record 0 if work browsing continues after 7 PM. Work means programming, work tools, professional research, work email.

indicators.name: evening_communication_free
indicators.how_to_measure: Record 1 if there are NO visits to work communication tools (Gmail, Outlook, Slack, Teams) after 6 PM. Record 0 if any such visits occur after 6 PM.

indicators.name: social_venue_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: On Saturday and Sunday only: Count searches for social venues and activities including restaurants, bars, cafes, events, parties, meetups, concerts, nightlife. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: social_location_lookups
indicators.how_to_measure: On Saturday and Sunday only: Count map views and location lookups for social places. Look for entries showing restaurants, cafes, entertainment venues, or searches for meeting spots and directions. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: hobby_leisure_browsing
indicators.how_to_measure: On Saturday and Sunday only: Count browsing for hobbies and leisure including music, travel planning, movies, books, games, creative activities, personal interest topics. Exclude work-related technical content. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: recreation_fitness_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: On Saturday and Sunday only: Count searches for physical recreation including exercise, sports, outdoor activities, hiking, beaches, swimming, diving, fitness, gym, nature activities. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: planning_tool_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to planning and organization tools: calendar apps such as Google Calendar, task managers such as Trello, Asana, Todoist, Notion, and any to-do list or scheduling tools.

indicators.name: morning_planning_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Record 1 if any planning or organization tool (calendar, task manager, to-do list) is visited between 6 AM and 10 AM. Record 0 if no planning tools are used in the morning.

indicators.name: fitness_exercise_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches related to fitness and exercise: workout, gym, running, yoga, swimming, cycling, fitness tracker, exercise routine, sports training, fitness app.

indicators.name: outdoor_activity_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches for outdoor physical activities: hiking, biking, trails, parks, beaches, diving, surfing, camping, nature walks, outdoor sports.

indicators.name: off_hours_work_activity
indicators.how_to_measure: Count work-related browsing during leisure time: all day on weekends, or after 8 PM on weekdays. Include work email, Slack, work documents, programming searches.

indicators.name: work_life_balance_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches related to work-life balance concerns: work guilt, productivity guilt, work-life balance, overwork, burnout, workaholic, hustle culture, taking time off, vacation guilt.

indicators.name: deadline_urgency_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches containing explicit deadline or urgency terms: deadline, urgent, due date, submit, due tomorrow, extension, rush, ASAP, overdue, on time, last minute.

indicators.name: very_late_work_session
indicators.how_to_measure: On weekdays only: Record 1 if work-related browsing occurs after 9 PM, suggesting deadline pressure requiring unusually late work. Record 0 if no work activity after 9 PM. If reviewing a weekend, record 0.

indicators.name: weekend_email_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: On Saturday and Sunday only: Count visits to email services such as Gmail, Outlook, Yahoo Mail, or any email client. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.

indicators.name: weekend_work_messaging
indicators.how_to_measure: On Saturday and Sunday only: Record 1 if any visit to work messaging platforms (Slack, Teams, Discord) occurs. Record 0 if no work messaging visits. If reviewing a weekday, record 0.
